Below is a structured, minimal-redundancy reading path. Pick one “core” text per stage, then use the others as references. I’ve grouped physics and math so you can learn concepts alongside their foundations.

Core QFT (pick 1 as your main, keep 1–2 as companions)
- Schwartz, Quantum Field Theory and the Standard Model (core, modern, SM-focused, lots of worked collider/QCD/EW examples).
- Peskin & Schroeder, An Introduction to QFT (classic calculations and intuition; great problem sets).
- Srednicki, QFT (modular chapters, clean renormalization and EFT presentation).
- Zee, QFT in a Nutshell (fast intuition, broad view; not a problem-book).
- Weinberg, The Quantum Theory of Fields, Vol. 1 (foundations; conceptually deep and precise; use selectively).
- Tong, QFT lecture notes (free, clear, excellent for first pass and revision).

Renormalization and RG (complements the above; do at least one deeply)
- Collins, Renormalization (conceptual + technical depth; MS scheme, OPE, factorization).
- Zinn-Justin, QFT and Critical Phenomena (encyclopedic RG; reference).
- Cardy, Scaling and Renormalization in Statistical Physics (pedagogical RG viewpoint).
- Wilson & Kogut, The renormalization group and the ε expansion (classic review).

Gauge fixing, ghosts, and BRST (short focused study)
- Weinberg, QToF Vol. 2, BRST chapters (concise and rigorous).
- Henneaux & Teitelboim, Quantization of Gauge Systems (standard reference).
- Piguet & Sorella, Algebraic Renormalization (for anomalies/renormalization in gauge theories).

QED (from basics to precision/IR structure)
- Schwartz or P&S: QED chapters (build perturbation theory, renormalization, IR).
- Berestetskii, Lifshitz, Pitaevskii, Quantum Electrodynamics (Landau–Lifshitz Vol. 4; compact, precise).
- Greiner & Reinhardt, QED of Strong Fields (if interested in bound states/strong-field).
- Weinberg, QToF Vol. 1–2: IR issues, KLN/Bloch–Nordsieck, asymptotics.
- Review: Aoyama et al., Theory of the Anomalous Magnetic Moment of the Electron (precision QED status).
- IR and asymptotic states: Kulish & Faddeev (original), or modern reviews on QED IR/superselection.

QCD (asymptotic freedom, factorization, colliders, nonperturbative)
- Schwartz or P&S: nonabelian gauge theory, asymptotic freedom, DGLAP, jets.
- Ellis, Stirling, Webber, QCD and Collider Physics (phenomenology, factorization, parton showers).
- Collins, Foundations of Perturbative QCD (factorization/OPE/SCET perspective).
- Sterman, An Introduction to QFT (strong on resummation and hard processes; advanced).
- Lattice QCD: Gattringer & Lang, Quantum Chromodynamics on the Lattice; or Rothe, Lattice Gauge Theories.
- Confinement/chiral symmetry: Greensite, An Introduction to the Confinement Problem; Polyakov, Gauge Fields and Strings (advanced, insightful).
- Chiral perturbation theory: Scherer & Schindler, A Primer for ChPT; Pich, Effective Field Theory notes.

Electroweak theory (SSB, Higgs, anomalies, precision)
- Aitchison & Hey, Gauge Theories in Particle Physics (2 vols; very pedagogical development of EW and QCD).
- Schwartz: EWSB, Higgs mechanism, precision EW, flavor.
- Weinberg, QToF Vol. 2: Spontaneously broken gauge theories, Goldstone theorem, anomalies.
- Quigg, Gauge Theories of the Strong, Weak, and Electromagnetic Interactions (phenomenological synthesis).
- Precision EW: Peskin & Takeuchi (S,T,U parameters) + PDG electroweak review; Denner, Techniques for the Calculation of Electroweak Radiative Corrections (advanced).

Effective Field Theory (you’ll use this across QED/QCD/EW)
- Petrov & Blechman, Effective Field Theories (modern, practical across SM/BSM).
- Manohar, TASI/lecture notes on EFT; Georgi, EFT (classic).
- SM EFT: Brivio & Trott, The Standard Model as an EFT (Comprehensive review).
- SCET: Becher/Neubert or Stewart lecture notes (for resummation/factorization).

Mathematical foundations (study alongside the physics; at least the first in each bullet)
- Lie groups, algebras, and reps:
  - Georgi, Lie Algebras in Particle Physics (particle-physics oriented).
  - Hall, Lie Groups, Lie Algebras, and Representations (mathematically clean).
  - Cvitanovic, Group Theory: Birdtracks (visual tensor methods, SU(N) mastery).
  - Slansky, Group Theory for Unified Model Building (review with rep tables).
- Geometry/topology of gauge fields:
  - Nakahara, Geometry, Topology and Physics (principal bundles, connections, Chern classes).
  - Frankel, The Geometry of Physics (differential forms approach; many examples).
  - Baez & Muniain, Gauge Fields, Knots and Gravity (gentle intro to bundles/curvature).
- Anomalies and index theorems:
  - Bertlmann, Anomalies in Quantum Field Theory (comprehensive).
  - Fujikawa & Suzuki, Path Integrals and Quantum Anomalies (Fujikawa method).
  - Bilal, Lectures on Anomalies; Harvey, TASI on anomalies (clear lecture notes).
- Functional methods and rigor (optional, for foundations):
  - Glimm & Jaffe, Quantum Physics: A Functional Integral Point of View (constructive QFT).
  - Itzykson & Zuber, QFT (reference-level breadth; dimensional regularization, loop tech).
  - Bogoliubov & Shirkov, Introduction to the Theory of Quantized Fields (classic axiomatic/renormalization).

Seminal papers to read alongside (historical and conceptual anchors)
- Yang & Mills (1954) nonabelian gauge fields; Faddeev–Popov (1967) ghosts.
- ’t Hooft (1971) renormalization of nonabelian gauge theories; ’t Hooft–Veltman (1972) renormalizability of spontaneously broken gauge theories.
- Higgs/Englert–Brout/Guralnik–Hagen–Kibble (1964) Higgs mechanism; Weinberg (1967), Salam (1968) electroweak unification; Glashow (1961).
- Gross–Wilczek and Politzer (1973) asymptotic freedom; Adler–Bell–Jackiw (1969) anomalies; Adler–Bardeen theorem.

How to use this list (a practical sequence)
1) Core QFT: Work through Schwartz (or P&S/Srednicki) end-to-end. Do problems from whichever main text you pick; use Tong’s notes as a quick second pass.
2) RG and gauge fixing: Read Collins Ch. 1–5 and Weinberg Vol. 2 on BRST to consolidate renormalization in gauge theories.
3) QED: Do the QED chapters in your core text thoroughly; then sample LL QED for compact mastery and read a short IR review.
4) QCD: Do nonabelian gauge theory, asymptotic freedom, and collinear/soft physics in your core text; then Ellis–Stirling–Webber for collider applications; Collins (2011) for factorization; optionally a lattice intro (Gattringer–Lang).
5) Electroweak: Aitchison & Hey or the EW chapters of Schwartz; follow with Weinberg Vol. 2 for SSB/anomalies; skim a precision-EW review (PDG, Peskin–Takeuchi).
6) EFT: Read Petrov & Blechman, then a SMEFT review (Brivio–Trott). If collider-focused, add SCET notes.
7) Math companion: In parallel, do Georgi (algebra/rep theory) and Nakahara (bundles/characteristic classes). Add Bertlmann or Fujikawa for anomalies once you hit EW/QCD triangle anomalies.

Handy reference/overview
- PDG Review of Particle Physics (up-to-date constants, concise topic reviews).
- Thomson, Modern Particle Physics or Griffiths, Introduction to Elementary Particles (fast phenomenology overview).

Optional modern methods (if interested)
- Elvang & Huang, Scattering Amplitudes in Gauge Theory and Gravity (on-shell methods).
- Dixon, TASI lectures on scattering amplitudes (concise notes).

If you want a minimal one-book path: Schwartz as the spine, plus Aitchison & Hey (EW+QCD pedagogy), Ellis–Stirling–Webber (QCD at colliders), Petrov & Blechman (EFT), Georgi (Lie algebras), and Nakahara (geometry/topology). Add PDG for ongoing reference.

Feel free to tell me your background and goals (theory vs. collider vs. lattice) and I can pare this to a shorter, personalized list.

Here’s a tight, field-standard path that will get you all the way through QED, the electroweak theory, and the essentials of QCD. I’ve kept it compact: a core spine of modern textbooks (with pinpointed chapters) plus a small canon of seminal papers you should actually read. If you follow the order, you’ll build the right scaffolding without detours.

# Core QFT spine (do one thoroughly, skim the others)

* **Peskin & Schroeder, *An Introduction to QFT*** (1995) — Chapters 2–7 (scalar/QED basics), 9–12 (renormalization), 15–16 (path integrals & gauge fixing), 17–21 (non-Abelian gauge theory & QCD intro). Work the exercises; they’re calibrated to collider/QCD culture.
* **Schwartz, *Quantum Field Theory and the Standard Model*** (2014) — Parts I–II for modern renormalization/LSZ; Part III (gauge theories), Part IV (EW theory), Part V (QCD, factorization, running). Clear on RG, anomalies, PDFs, and practical QCD.
* **Weinberg, *The Quantum Theory of Fields*, Vol. I–II** (1995–96) — For a axiomatic and symmetry-first perspective. Use Vol. I Ch. 5–12 (symmetries, S-matrix, renormalization) and Vol. II Ch. 15–22 (non-Abelian gauge theory, anomalies, BRST). Dip in to check conceptual foundations.

(If you want a lighter ramp or a second voice: **Aitchison & Hey, *Gauge Theories in Particle Physics*, Vol. 1–2** (4th ed.)—pedagogically excellent for EW symmetry breaking and QCD phenomenology.)

# QED: from basics to precision

* **Itzykson & Zuber, *Quantum Field Theory*** (1980) — Ch. 6–8 (spinor QED, Ward identities, vacuum polarization). Old-school but surgical derivations.
* **Srednicki, *Quantum Field Theory*** (2007) — Ch. 33–44 for renormalized QED with a crisp path-integral treatment and modern conventions.
* **Schweber, *QED and the Men Who Made It*** (1994) — Not a textbook, but reading the narrative around Dyson–Feynman–Schwinger–Tomonaga clarifies what the formalism is *for* (especially Ward–Takahashi identities and renormalization).

# Electroweak unification: the working theory

* **Cheng & Li, *Gauge Theory of Elementary Particle Physics*** (1984) — Still one of the clearest full treatments. Do Ch. 5–8 (Yang–Mills, SSB, Higgs), Ch. 9–10 (EW phenomenology).
* **Quigg, *Gauge Theories of the Strong, Weak, and Electromagnetic Interactions*** (2nd ed., 2013) — Conceptual overview with careful phenomenology; use as glue after Cheng–Li.
* **Aitchison & Hey, Vol. 2** — Pedagogical derivation of the EW sector, CKM, neutral currents, precision tests (S, T, U intuition).

# QCD essentials (running, confinement heuristics, and collider basics)

* **Ellis, Stirling & Webber, *QCD and Collider Physics*** (1996) — Gold standard for perturbative QCD, parton model, factorization, jets, event shapes. Read Ch. 1–5, 7–9.
* **Sterman, *An Introduction to QFT*** (1993) — Factorization theorems and resummation ideas at a rigorous level; use selected chapters for depth.
* **Peskin & Schroeder** — Revisit Ch. 16–21: asymptotic freedom, ghosts/BRST, beta function, deep inelastic scattering, parton evolution.

# Renormalization, RG, and anomalies (to “close the loop” conceptually)

* **Collins, *Renormalization*** (1984) — The cleanest proof-heavy treatment; read early chapters plus the Wilsonian parts as needed.
* **Zinn-Justin, *QFT and Critical Phenomena*** (4th ed.) — For Wilsonian RG perspective; skim the sections that map directly to gauge theories.
* **Georgi, *Lie Algebras in Particle Physics*** (2nd ed.) — Minimal but sufficient group theory for SU(2)×U(1), SU(3), reps, anomalies, and model-building hygiene.

# Seminal papers (short, canonical, and genuinely worth reading)

**QED / renormalization**

* Dyson (1949) — Series expansions & renormalization structure.
* Ward (1950); Ward–Takahashi identities (various) — Current conservation ⇒ charge renormalization relations.
* Schwinger (1948–51); Feynman (1949) — Foundational QED formalisms.
* Kinoshita (1990s) & Aoyama et al. (2010s) — Electron (g-2) state-of-the-art (skim for what “precision QED” entails).

**Yang–Mills & renormalizability**

* Yang & Mills (1954) — Non-Abelian gauge fields.
* ’t Hooft (1971); ’t Hooft & Veltman (1972) — Renormalizability of non-Abelian gauge theories and dimensional regularization.

**Electroweak theory**

* Glashow (1961) — SU(2)×U(1) electroweak idea.
* Weinberg (1967); Salam (1968) — Spontaneously broken EW theory with masses.
* Higgs (1964); Englert–Brout (1964); Guralnik–Hagen–Kibble (1964) — Mass generation via SSB (read at least one fully).
* Cabibbo (1963); Kobayashi–Maskawa (1973) — Flavor mixing and CPV (CKM).

**QCD / asymptotic freedom / scaling**

* Gross & Wilczek (1973); Politzer (1973) — Asymptotic freedom.
* Altarelli & Parisi (1977); Gribov–Lipatov (1972); Dokshitzer (1977) — DGLAP evolution (read AP for pedagogy).
* Friedman–Kendall–Taylor (late 1960s) — DIS scaling data (skim to connect theory↔experiment).

**Anomalies**

* Adler (1969); Bell–Jackiw (1969) — Chiral anomaly (ABJ).
* Bardeen (1969) — Anomaly structure in gauge theories (consistency conditions).

# How to use this (minimal but complete plan)

1. **One modern text end-to-end**: Do **Schwartz** or **Peskin** thoroughly (including problem sets). You’ll cover QED, renormalization, gauge fixing, beta functions.
2. **Lock in EW**: Read **Aitchison & Hey (Vol. 2)** or **Cheng & Li** on SSB, the Higgs mechanism, neutral/charged currents, and precision constraints; then skim **Weinberg Vol. II** for the clean formal view.
3. **QCD basics with phenomenology**: Do **Ellis–Stirling–Webber** Ch. 1–5, 7–9 (parton model, running, factorization, jets). Supplement with DGLAP papers and Gross–Wilczek/Politzer.
4. **Conceptual closure**: Sample **Collins** (renormalization) and **Georgi** (group theory) where you feel gaps: anomalies, BRST, representation theory.
5. **Primary sources**: Read **Weinberg (1967)**, **’t Hooft (1971/72)**, **Gross–Wilczek/Politzer (1973)**, **Altarelli–Parisi (1977)** carefully with the textbooks open. It cements derivations with the original logic.

# Optional but high-yield add-ons

* **Maggiore, *A Modern Introduction to QFT*** — Streamlined path-integral pedagogy with clean exercises.
* **Dreiner, Haber, Martin, *Two-Component Spinor Techniques* (arXiv)** — Makes chiral structures in EW and SUSY less painful.
* **Pokorski, *Gauge Field Theories*** — Clear, compact treatment of gauge theories and SSB.

---

If you want, I can turn this into a one-semester/one-year reading schedule with problem sets mapped to each chapter and a shortlist of classic calculations (electron (g-2), QED beta function, EW mixing and (M_W/M_Z), one-loop QCD beta function, LO DGLAP) so you come out with both conceptual mastery and calculational fluency.
